article:
{{Infobox music genre |name=Roots rock |color=white |bgcolor=crimson
|stylistic_origins=Rock, country, blues, folk, folk rock, rock and roll, roots
revival |cultural_origins=1960s, United States |instruments=Guitar (acoustic,
electric and pedal steel), piano, drums, bass guitar |popularity=Late 1960s and
early 1970s, revival in 1980s |derivatives= |subgenrelist= |subgenres=Country
rock, Southern rock, heartland rock, swamp rock |fusiongenres=Alternative
country, cowpunk
| regional_scenes = local_scenes = other_topics = Americana, indie folk
}} 'Roots rock' is rock music that looks back to rock's origins in folk, blues
and country music. P. Auslander, Liveness: performance in a mediatized
culture (London: Routledge, 2008), p. 83. It is particularly associated
with the creation of hybrid sub-genres from the later 1960s including country
rock and Southern rock, which have been seen as responses to the perceived
excesses of dominant psychedelic and developing progressive rock. V. Bogdanov, C. Woodstra and S. T. Erlewine, All music guide to rock: the
definitive guide to rock, pop, and soul (Backbeat Books, 3rd edn., 2002), p.
1327. Because roots music (Americana) is often used to mean folk and world
musical forms, roots rock is sometimes used in a broad sense to describe any
rock music that incorporates elements of this music. R. Shuker, Popular
Music: the Key Concepts (London: Routledge, 2005), p. 235. In the 1980s
roots rock enjoyed a revival in response to trends in punk rock, New Wave and
heavy metal music.
